results.title: Rain in the sun
results.brief_description: In some regions of Japan a sunshower is known as a “Kitsune no Yomein” which literally means “Foxes’ Wedding”. This simplistic poetic 2-d animated tale illustrates the legend behind “Kitsune no Yomein”. Introduction in Japanese language with English subtitles.

results.title: Rain check on Christmas
results.brief_description: A father and his daughter re-tell the events that happened two days before Christmas, when the father was struck down with a heart attack. Made as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’ in association with Vic Health and the Heart Foundation.

results.title: Rain
results.creator_credit: Christine Jeffs, Philippa Campbell, Communicado, Rose Road and New Zealand Film Commission
results.brief_description: Based on the novel “Rain” by Kirsty Gunn from New Zealand filmmaker Christine Jeffs comes the story of an adolescent girl’s life-changing summer holiday. The girl’s parent’s marriage is not strong and her mother has an affair with another holiday-maker, fuelled along by alcohol. Confusion and jealousy occur in the young girl’s mind as she tries to come to terms with her own sexual awakening while trying to decipher adult relationships. Moody and atmospheric, the pace of the film is as leisurely as the holiday with gentle seaside in the day and partying parents at night. A mix of carefree playfulness (as the girl and her young brother frolic in this idyll) with a darker foreboding and uneasiness just under the surface. Original soundtrack by Neil Finn. Cast includes Alicia Fulford-Wierzbicki, Sarah Peirse, Marton Csokas, Alistair Browning, Aaron Murphy.

results.title: Rain
results.creator_credit: Lewis Milestone, Joseph Schenck and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Joan Crawford stars as prostitute Sadie Thompson, in this version of Somerset Maugham’s story of lust in the sultry Pacific. From her first entrance, ring-studded hand on a door jamb, followed by an undulating body in a skin tight checked outfit, Crawford dominates the film as she goes on to seduce Walter Huston’s stern straight-laced missionary. The variable quality of the soundtrack is due to the quality of the original film and is not the fault of the video.

results.title: Railways of yesteryear
results.creator_credit: John Mabey, Rhonda Mabey and Sorena
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
A must for all railway enthusiasts; a journey into the past on trains from the “golden age of steam” and through some of Australia’s most spectacular and breathtaking scenery. We ride the famous Zig Zag in the Blue Mountains (NSW), see three steam trains race side by side on modern suburban tracks in Sydney, watch Puffing Billy steaming its way through the Dandenong Ranges (Vic), then across to SA for an ambling trip on Australia’s first public railway line - the old horse-drawn tram in Victor Harbour, the Pichi Richi railway in the Flinders Ranges and finally the ultimate - a trip on both the Old and the New Ghan across Central Australia providing a glimpse of the past and the future. Narrated by Ted Eagan.

results.title: Railways of Australia
results.creator_credit: William M. Carty, Frank Killian, Commonwealth Railways and Cinesound Movietone
results.brief_description: Surveys the railway system in Australia today, and the need for its maintenance and improvement to meet the ever-increasing calls for all forms of quick and efficient transportation. Stresses the importance of railways for carrying large numbers of people and raw materials.

results.title: Railways for ever
results.creator_credit: Norman Prouting and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: The last steam train crossing the Pennines and an Edwardian concert hall song “Watching the trains go out”, bring back many memories to Sir John Betjeman. In his own nostalgic verse and prose, he remembers the great trains of old and looks forward to railways for ever as he moves through a photographic exhibition.

results.title: Railways at work
results.creator_credit: Bern Gandy, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Transport in Australia”.
Shows the vital role of railways in Australia’s economy. Includes scenes from each state to illustrate rolling stock, services and people who depend on railways, directly or indirectly.
